content.raw:
One idea:

* Add a flag to indicate whether world pose is cached (it is for models and links at the moment).

* Change GetWorldPose so it returns the cached value according to the flag or recomputes it based on the parent world pose.

Or:

* Make GetWorldPose virtual and overload it for Collisions.

Should we do a [design doc review](#!/osrf/gazebo_design) for this?
content.html:
One idea:

  • Add a flag to indicate whether world pose is cached (it is for models and links at the moment).

  • Change GetWorldPose so it returns the cached value according to the flag or recomputes it based on the parent world pose.

Or:

  • Make GetWorldPose virtual and overload it for Collisions.

Should we do a design doc review for this?

content.raw:
The world pose is cached for all derived classes of entity, which includes Model, Link, Collision. The problem is that on a pose change, only the Model and Link poses were updated. 

This hasn't been an issue because the world pose of a collision is not accessed frequently. 

The best solution is to override `Entity::GetWorldPose` in `Collision`. I'll work on a prototype, and see how that pans out.

Consider this discussion the design document. Let's leave design document for new features, and see how the process works. I'm hesitant to require a design document for every issue.
content.html:
The world pose is cached for all derived classes of entity, which includes Model, Link, Collision. The problem is that on a pose change, only the Model and Link poses were updated.

This hasn't been an issue because the world pose of a collision is not accessed frequently.

The best solution is to override Entity::GetWorldPose in Collision. I'll work on a prototype, and see how that pans out.

Consider this discussion the design document. Let's leave design document for new features, and see how the process works. I'm hesitant to require a design document for every issue.

content.raw: We can consider this the design document. At the time I wasn't sure how good my ideas were and thought we might need additional eyes, but it looks like you've resolved it quickly by overloading.
content.html: We can consider this the design document. At the time I wasn't sure how good my ideas were and thought we might need additional eyes, but it looks like you've resolved it quickly by overloading.

content.raw: Updated. The performance impact is near zero, unless `Collision::GetWorldPose` is called a lot.
content.html: Updated. The performance impact is near zero, unless Collision::GetWorldPose is called a lot.

content.raw:
There was a comment here from @scpeters that was lost in the updates. Copying it here for better visibility:

-   Do we need a mutex for this?

I think we probably do as `GetWorldPose()` could be called from other threads such as the sensor thread.
content.html:
There was a comment here from @scpeters that was lost in the updates. Copying it here for better visibility:

  • Do we need a mutex for this?

I think we probably do as GetWorldPose() could be called from other threads such as the sensor thread.

content.raw:
I don't we need the mutex. The `SetWorldPoseDirty` function is a single operation that always sets `worldPoseDirty` to true. The `GetWorldPose` function reads `worldPoseDirty` once, and conditionally writes to it once.   

Running through the cases, the only bad case would be recomputing `worldPose` unnecessarily once. This would happen if `SetWorldPoseDirty` is executed right after `this->worldPoseDirty = false`. This is okay, especially if we can avoid adding a mutex.
content.html:
I don't we need the mutex. The SetWorldPoseDirty function is a single operation that always sets worldPoseDirty to true. The GetWorldPose function reads worldPoseDirty once, and conditionally writes to it once.

Running through the cases, the only bad case would be recomputing worldPose unnecessarily once. This would happen if SetWorldPoseDirty is executed right after this->worldPoseDirty = false. This is okay, especially if we can avoid adding a mutex.

content.raw:
I didn't write this at the time, but I was observing infrequent test failures. For example, the `Issue1124Test.SetModelPose` test has failed for me with the following error:
~~~
[ RUN      ] Issue1124Test.SetModelPose
[Msg] Waiting for master.
[Msg] Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
[Msg] Publicized address: 192.168.1.183
[Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:144] ServerFixture load in 0.7 seconds, timeout after 600 seconds
/home/scpeters/ws/gazebo/src/gazebo/test/regression/1124_collision_pose.cc:49: Failure
Value of: math::Pose(2, 2, 0.5, 0, 0, 0)
  Actual: 2 2 0.5 0 0 0
Expected: coll->GetWorldPose()
Which is: 0 0 0.5 -1e-06 -0 0
[Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:95] ServerFixture::Unload
[  FAILED  ] Issue1124Test.SetModelPose (836 ms)
~~~
It's pretty infrequent, not sure what would cause that.

content.raw:
I updated the test in branch issue_1124_scpeters (79569bb2798f and 9515cbdbe129) to check the link pose and model pose in addition to collision pose:
~~~
    EXPECT_EQ(model->GetWorldPose(), newPose);
    EXPECT_EQ(link->GetWorldPose(), newPose);
    EXPECT_EQ(coll->GetWorldPose(), newPose);
~~~
 These additions made the test fail much less frequently (it took at least 10 times as many tries to observe a failure), but when it does fail, the link and collision poses fail together, ie:
~~~
[ RUN      ] Issue1124Test.SetModelPose
[Msg] Waiting for master.
[Msg] Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
[Msg] Publicized address: 192.168.1.183
[Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:144] ServerFixture load in 1 seconds, timeout after 600 seconds
/home/scpeters/ws/gazebo/src/gazebo/test/regression/1124_collision_pose.cc:57: Failure
Value of: newPose
  Actual: 2 2 0.5 0 0 0
Expected: link->GetWorldPose()
Which is: 0 0 0.5 0 0 0
/home/scpeters/ws/gazebo/src/gazebo/test/regression/1124_collision_pose.cc:58: Failure
Value of: newPose
  Actual: 2 2 0.5 0 0 0
Expected: coll->GetWorldPose()
Which is: 0 0 0.5 0 0 0
[Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:95] ServerFixture::Unload
[  FAILED  ] Issue1124Test.SetModelPose (1138 ms)
~~~

I updated the test in branch issue_1124_scpeters (79569bb2798f and 9515cbdbe129) to check the link pose and model pose in addition to collision pose:

    EXPECT_EQ(model->GetWorldPose(), newPose);
    EXPECT_EQ(link->GetWorldPose(), newPose);
    EXPECT_EQ(coll->GetWorldPose(), newPose);

These additions made the test fail much less frequently (it took at least 10 times as many tries to observe a failure), but when it does fail, the link and collision poses fail together, ie:

[ RUN      ] Issue1124Test.SetModelPose

content.raw:
I think is happening when the physics engine updates the pose of the link right after the test sets the pose of the model. Commenting out [this line](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/075e871093dc663fd0c94f3e506d40f7631bc334/gazebo/physics/World.cc?at=default#cl-674) seems to "fix" it.

Using the WorldPoseMutex doesn't work due to deadlock.

I can fix the test by running the world paused.

On the plus side, this error case won't happen for plugins or programs using the transport library. It'll only be a problem if you happen to run the world in one thread and use the API in another thread.
content.html:
I think is happening when the physics engine updates the pose of the link right after the test sets the pose of the model. Commenting out this line seems to "fix" it.

Using the WorldPoseMutex doesn't work due to deadlock.

I can fix the test by running the world paused.

On the plus side, this error case won't happen for plugins or programs using the transport library. It'll only be a problem if you happen to run the world in one thread and use the API in another thread.

content.raw: Ok, let's run the test paused then.
content.html: Ok, let's run the test paused then.

content.html: Done. And issue #1201 captures the problem.
